actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned pursuant to a previous special order. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 p.m. on May 15, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Clyde moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.

Mr. Rogers (KY) asked unanimous consent That when the House adjourns on Thursday, May 11, 2023, it adjourn to meet at noon on Monday, May 15, 2023 for Morning-Hour debate and 2:00 p.m. for legislative business. Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification of the continuation of the national emergency with respect to Yemen declared in Executive Order 13611 of May 16, 2012, is to continue in effect beyond May 16, 2023
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-40).

actions-list.header: Board of Visitors to the United States Military Academy
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 10 U.S.C 7455(a), and the order the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following member of the House to the Board of Visitors to the United States Military Academy: Mr. Ryan.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
The House observed a moment of silence in honor of the victims of the recent Interstate 55 dust storm vehicular crash in Illinois.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 425
actions-list.actionItem: 0 (Roll no. 212).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1734 — "To require coordinated National Institute of Standards and Technology science and research activities regarding illicit drugs containing xylazine, novel synthetic opioids, and other substances of concern, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by recorded vote: 230
On motion to recommit Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 210

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1163 — "To provide incentives for States to recover fraudulently paid Federal and State unemployment compensation, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 219
On motion to recommit Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 211

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 2 — "To secure the borders of the United States, and for other purposes."

The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on the motion to recommit H.R. 2, passage of H.R. 2, if ordered, the motion to recommit H.R. 1163, passage of H.R. 1163, if ordered, and the motion to suspend the rules and pass H.R. 1734, as amended, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.

The Chair put the question on the motion to recommit the bill and by voice vote announced the noes had prevailed. Mrs. Sykes demanded the yeas and nays, and the Chair postoned further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Mrs. Sykes moved to recommit to the Committee on Ways and Means.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 1163.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 2 and H.R. 1163. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 2 under a closed rule with five hours of general debate, and the resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 1163 under a closed rule with one hour of general debate. The resolution provides for a motion to recommit on each measure.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 383. H.R. 1163 — "To provide incentives for States to recover fraudulently paid Federal and State unemployment compensation, and for other purposes."

The Chair put the question on the motion to recommit the bill and by voice vote announced the noes had prevailed. Ms. Garcia (TX) demanded the yeas and nays, and the Chair postoned further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Ms. Garcia (TX) moved to recommit to the Committee on the Judiciary.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House resumed with further debate on H.R. 2.
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 2 — "To secure the borders of the United States, and for other purposes."
Pursuant to clause 1(c) of rule XIX, the Chair announced that consideration of H.R. 2 would now resume.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 minutes per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Tiffany to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 11.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 11:00 a.m. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 11:00 a.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable C. Scott Franklin to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
